0.content: Hey there! One of the backlog is to identify low-level requirements of the users. I was wondering how can we go about this?

1.content: There are many ways to empathize with users. One way is to perform user interviews!

2.content: As part of user research, user interviews are a way to gather more in-depth data and research to better understand on our users

3.content: Deciding the right person to interview and designing the right interview questions are important.

4.content:
Let's roleplay! I will pretend to be the user. 
*wears chicken mask* 
Start by asking me a question!

options.text: What is the hardest part about your task?
I was talking to another participant and they said this is the hardest part about the task. Do you agree with it?

5.content: That's a good question! It is quite open ended, great job!

6.content: That's not an ideal question. It would bring other participants' influence into the interview, causing bias.

7.content: Try to keep the interview within the context of the user you are interviewing, that's the golden rule!

options.text: Which feature is the most important to you: A or B?
What features do you use? Which of it is the most important for you?

9.content: Unforunately, providing options in interviews is not ideal. The user may end up choosing an option even when none matches just because, well, there aren't any other options.

10.content: This can leave out valuable information. Thus, a better way is to ask what feature do they use, and which they find more important!

11.content: That way, we can find what matters most to the user. Remember, open-ended questions are the way!

12.content: That's a great question! Asking an open-ended question ensures that the user's answers are not limited to the options we provide.

13.content: I've definitely learnt alot, thanks for this insightful session!
